claim: AI-Powered Actions are GitHub Actions that leverage Claude Code CLI to provide intelligent automation capabilities
Self-hosted runner is the execution environment for Claude Code CLI
Project has three phases: Foundation & POC (COMPLETED), AI Action Hub Implementation (COMPLETED), Stabilization & Adoption (In Progress)
review-and-merge action reviews PR content using AI and automatically merges if LGTM
review-and-merge provides intelligent code review with confidence scoring, automatic issue fixing, custom review rules, and LGTM/auto-merge support
spec-to-code converts Markdown specifications into production-ready code with multi-language support
auto-refactor intelligently refactors code to improve quality and maintainability with context-aware analysis
auto-document keeps documentation synchronized with code changes automatically through intelligent code analysis
release-notes-ai generates comprehensive release notes from commit history and PRs with AI-powered summarization
action-fixer automatically detects and fixes GitHub Actions workflow syntax errors with YAML syntax validation and automatic error correction
LGTM (Looks Good To Me) is a threshold-based approval mechanism for PR review with configurable threshold values
PR Quality Gate is a workflow pattern ensuring code quality before merging using AI review, refactoring, and documentation updates
Spec-Driven Development is a workflow pattern where code and tests are generated from Markdown specifications
Product goal is to provide AI-native GitHub Actions hub using Claude Code CLI for organizational development efficiency and quality improvement
Success metrics include: Action adoption count, AI suggestion quality (Acceptance Rate), and development efficiency (human focus time increase)
Non-goals include: simple shell script wrappers, fully unmanned operation, and tight coupling to specific products
Milestones: MS-001 (Phase 3: Stabilization & Adoption - active), MS-002 (Phase 4: Quality & Performance - planned), MS-003 (Phase 5: Advanced Features - planned)
Work policy requires PR mode, iteration budget limits (max 5 cycles, 25 files, 800 LOC), quality gates (lint, test), and concept sync v0.3 with bloat control as failure
Claude Code CLI is installed globally on self-hosted runners via npm for executing AI-powered operations
GitHub token requires contents:write, pull-requests:write, and issues:write scopes for action operations
Adoption Guide provides complete roadmap for teams to adopt AI Actions in their repositories
Self-hosted Runner must be Linux environment (recommended Ubuntu 20.04+)
GitHub Token requires contents:read (minimum), pull-requests:write (for PR operations), issues:write (for issue operations)
release-notes-ai is beginner-friendly action with low difficulty and no risk (code changesなし)
action-fixer is beginner-friendly action with low risk (notifications only in dry run mode)
claude-model is required input parameter for actions (e.g., claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929)
dry_run mode executes action without saving changes for initial testing
Version management policy: use @main for development/testing, @v1 for production, NEVER use @main in production
For development/testing use local path: ./actions/action-name
For production use: your-org/github-actions-actions/actions/action-name@v1
action-fixer has comprehensive test suite with 15 tests covering parsing, validation, and error detection
Test coverage increased from 95.03% to 95.29% (+0.26%) with action-fixer test suite
BMAD Implementation/Test Flow is a workflow for implementing and testing stories in BMAD methodology
BMAD workflow file at .claude/commands/bmad/bmm/workflows/full-bmad-project-flow/2-implementation-test-flow.md is incomplete (5 lines only)
workflow.xml is core workflow execution engine referenced by BMAD but does not exist
Total 32 stories with status All Complete, completion period Dec 2025 - Jan 2026

15 implemented actions: action-fixer, auto-document, auto-merge, auto-rebase, auto-refactor, bulk-merge-prs, bulk-rebase-prs, pr-review-enqueuer, publish-pr, release-notes-ai, review-and-merge, review-auto-merge, spec-to-code, _shared
Test suite exists in /tests/ directory with test files for test_action_fixer, test_review_and_merge, test_spec_to_code and pytest configuration
BMAD workflow framework missing critical components: workflow.xml core execution engine, workflow YAML configurations, complete workflow instruction files
Project was implemented without using BMAD automated workflow system; stories, actions, and tests were created manually or through different process
BMAD Implementation/Test Flow cannot be executed as intended because: workflow definition incomplete, workflow.xml doesn't exist, implementation already complete, actions implemented and tested
BMAD workflow infrastructure requires: complete workflow.xml core execution engine, fleshed out workflow.md files with instructions, workflow-specific YAML configurations
Repository main branch is 20 commits ahead of origin with clean working tree
Temporary workflow execution report file removed as cleanup (deleted 94 lines)
Structural testing approach validates GitHub Actions' structure, syntax, and configuration without executing them in GitHub Actions runtime environment
Structural tests catch: YAML syntax errors, missing required files, incorrect action structure, breaking changes to action interfaces

Test Coverage includes: YAML syntax validity, required inputs defined, optional inputs have defaults, template files exist, script files exist and referenced, directory structure correct, security patterns present, action uses composite run type, action uses bash shell
Structural tests do NOT validate: actual action execution, real GitHub API interactions, Claude CLI invocation, file operations, error handling in practice, output values
Each action has two test classes: Test[ActionName]Action (unit tests for individual components) and Test[ActionName]Integration (integration tests for YAML parsing and directory structure)
Test Coverage: 168 tests (13 actions), 97.51% coverage, test types: structural/smoke tests only
Tests don't verify actions actually work when executed (no functional testing) - bugs in action logic won't be caught
String-in-file testing: tests verify strings exist in files, not that they're used correctly - typos or incorrect usage might not be caught

Phase 2 Integration Testing (Planned): Add tests that execute actions in controlled environments using act for local GitHub Actions execution, mock GitHub API responses, create test repositories, verify action outputs
Phase 3 End-to-End Testing (Future): Test complete workflows with real GitHub API - create test GitHub repositories, execute actions via real GitHub API, verify results, cleanup test data
Structural testing provides: fast feedback (milliseconds), high coverage (97.51%), catches common errors (YAML syntax, missing files), maintainable (simple to understand and modify)
Project prioritizes speed and maintainability with structural tests, while recognizing need for functional tests for higher confidence
Functional Testing includes Phase 2 Integration Testing (Planned) and Phase 3 End-to-End Testing (Future) for runtime validation
Adoption Registry tracks the adoption of AI Hub Actions across the organization with statistics on teams, repositories, and action usage
Adoption statistics include: Total Teams (0), Total Repositories (0), Most Used Actions (TBD)
Adoption Process: Review Available Actions, Choose Actions, Test in Staging, Roll Out, Provide Feedback
Adoption Registry helps track: Organizational Reach (team count), Action Popularity (most used actions), User Satisfaction (collective feedback), Impact Assessment (workflow improvements)
BMAD Implementation/Test Flow completed successfully: 32 stories (100%), 13 GitHub Actions, 97.51% test coverage, 168/168 tests passing
Test distribution: 13 actions tested, coverage range 96-100%, all 168 tests passing, execution time 0.49s
Repo Genesis Audit Verdict: EXCELLENT - READY FOR ORGANIZATIONAL ADOPTION, Overall Score 4/4 (100%), Technical Health 97.51% coverage, Critical Gaps 0, Status STABLE
Project Phases: Phase 1 Foundation COMPLETE, Phase 2 Development COMPLETE, Phase 3 Stabilization COMPLETE, Phase 4 Adoption IN PROGRESS (Organizational), Phase 5 Optimization PLANNED (Post-Adoption)

E2E Testing Gap (HIGH - Deferred): Current structural tests provide adequate coverage for stabilization phase, E2E tests require self-hosted runners with Claude CLI which are not yet available, Decision: Implement when pilot deployment begins
Organizational Adoption Gap (MEDIUM - In Progress): Technical preparation complete, Current State 0 teams 0 repositories, Waiting for organizational readiness and pilot teams

Repo Autopilot System Run 10 completed: Discovery phase found all 168 tests passing, no CI errors, concept sync healthy with 26 terms, 0 ambiguities, 0 conflicts. MS-001 (Phase 3: Stabilization & Adoption) remains active. System ready for organizational adoption.

Repo Autopilot System Run 13 completed: Discovery phase confirmed MS-001 (Phase 3: Stabilization & Adoption) is substantially complete. All 13 AI Actions have complete instructions and examples. Test suite: 168/168 passing, 97.51% coverage. Quality gates met: INV-001 through INV-009 validated. System is in maintenance mode, ready for MS-002 (Phase 4: Quality & Performance). Concept Sync v0.3 operating normally with 26 terms, 0 ambiguities, 0 conflicts. Bloat control metrics: 26 total terms (well under 80 limit), draft_ratio 0.00. No uncommitted changes detected.
Custom review rules allow injecting project-specific guidelines to tailor AI behavior to coding standards, security requirements, and architectural patterns
custom-rules is an input parameter that accepts YAML-formatted rules to be injected into AI review process
review-and-merge has two modes: Auto-Fix (applies corrections directly) and Review (posts feedback as comment)
Custom Rules Tutorial is a step-by-step guide for creating and testing custom review rules for review-and-merge action
Python style rules enforce PEP 8 compliance, type hints, docstrings, error handling, Pythonic code patterns, import conventions, performance, and testing standards
Security rules enforce credential management, input validation, authentication and authorization, data protection, API security, dependency management, and logging
React patterns rules enforce hooks best practices, component design, performance optimization, and state management patterns
TypeScript strict rules enforce strict mode configuration, explicit typing, no implicit any, and proper type annotations

Custom rules ecosystem includes: comprehensive documentation (review-and-merge-custom-rules.md), ready-to-use templates (examples/custom-rules/), and step-by-step tutorial (examples/custom-rules-tutorial.md)
Custom rules workflow: create .github/review-rules.yml with rules, reference in workflow file using cat command and GITHUB_OUTPUT
AcceptanceTracker is a class that tracks acceptance rate metrics for AI-generated suggestions by recording suggestions_made, suggestions_accepted, suggestions_rejected, and suggestions_modified
get_acceptance_rate() calculates acceptance rate as (suggestions_accepted / suggestions_made) * 100, returning 0.0 if no suggestions made
QA-001: Acceptance Rate >= 80% is the primary quality goal for MS-002 (Phase 4: Quality & Performance)
Acceptance rate tracking measures AI suggestion quality through four metrics: Suggestions Made, Suggestions Accepted, Suggestions Rejected, and Suggestions Modified
Four AI-powered actions have acceptance tracking integrated: review-and-merge, spec-to-code, action-fixer, and auto-refactor
Metrics are collected through: 1) Tracking Integration in each action, 2) Daily Aggregation via GitHub Workflow, 3) Automated Report Generation

AcceptanceTracker has comprehensive test suite covering initialization, recording outcomes (made/accepted/rejected/modified), rate calculations (acceptance/rejection/modification), and edge cases (0%, 100%)
Acceptance Rate Tracking measures the quality and effectiveness of AI-generated suggestions by tracking suggestions made, accepted, rejected, and modified
AcceptanceTracker is a class that tracks acceptance rate metrics for AI-generated suggestions with action_name and metrics attributes
Acceptance rate is calculated as (suggestions_accepted / suggestions_made) * 100, returning 0.0 if no suggestions made
Rejection rate is calculated as (suggestions_rejected / suggestions_made) * 100, returning 0.0 if no suggestions made
Modification rate is calculated as (suggestions_modified / suggestions_made) * 100, returning 0.0 if no suggestions made
export_metrics returns a dictionary containing action name, timestamp, metrics, and calculated rates (acceptance_rate, rejection_rate, modification_rate)
save_to_file persists metrics to JSON file by appending new data to existing data
AcceptanceTracker initializes with action_name and zero metrics for suggestions_made, suggestions_accepted, suggestions_rejected, suggestions_modified
Acceptance rate returns 0.0 when no suggestions made, and (accepted/made)*100 otherwise
save_to_file creates JSON file with list containing metric entries with action, timestamp, metrics, and rates
Acceptance rate tracking measures AI suggestion quality by tracking suggestions made, accepted, rejected, and modified
QA-001 is the quality goal requiring Acceptance Rate >= 80% defined in .audit/config/intent.yml for MS-002
AI-powered actions with acceptance tracking include: review-and-merge, spec-to-code, action-fixer, auto-refactor
aggregate-metrics.yml workflow runs daily at midnight UTC, aggregates metrics from last 7 days, generates acceptance rate report, commits to repository, and uploads artifacts with 30-day retention

Adoption Registry tracks organizational adoption including team count, repository count, most used actions, team registrations with privacy options (Public/Anonymous/Private), feedback summary, and success metrics
Adoption Registry tracks Total Teams, Total Repositories, and Most Used Actions as statistics
Adoption Registry helps track organizational reach, action popularity, user satisfaction, and impact assessment
